body: The 2nd pull request came in during the processing of the first, which explains why the process fails for the first.

Removing the dummy* jars is OK, as they should be already generated by:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/4abdad79e682d4d93ebc92ff986e82bf0c0d44a1

But removing the empty.jar will likely fail the tests.

Jan

@dukescript would you please squash related or "unimportant" commits, so we do not pollute git history too much ? Thanks.
@lkishalmi , can you please review the fix
I need to test this. What happens if there is no EOL character at the end of file?
If last character is not  '\n'  then there is no issue in double clicking and dragging the mouse to select text

@sdedic Thanks a lot for testing. I think in this case having detailed history is useful, as the commits contain the info of the required steps. So if someone is facing a similar problem, or the approach needs to be updated/enhanced for future releases, having the individual commits will be helpful for understanding what's going on.
Thank you for looking at it, Svatopluk!
For the record, this patch resolves https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1159
Is it really need to be cherry picked? Assertions are disabled in releases.

Also removed the reference of CMS GC from netbeans.conf as it got deprecated in Java 9.
Removed the minimum heap size as of 32 megs, which would be the default when using Netbeans on a machine with 1Gb ram as it is the 1/64th of the available ram, it is often greater on modern machines. So removing that theoretically could speed up the boot performance.

The same code serves as a platform for NetBeans based applications where different rules may apply. Unless assertions are disabled, it may prevent from developing + using apps that use "eager" fragments (see the initial comment). 
Since it is a **regression** introduced during 10 dev cycle, it might break existing NB9 based applications. This issue is not so important for **NetBeans IDE**, but may be for **NetBeans Platform**.

My 2 cents. Release coordinator should decide.
Only to let you know, I created a ticket for the Splashscreen: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1444
Cherry picked to release100

Usually no separate PR is required fro cherry-pick marked ones, only in the case when for some reason the PR would be different.
Right now I had only conflict om the release version in manifest.mf. As 10.0 has not been released yet I've kept the 1.28.1.
See: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/29b71ba0df192b480c90d46febdcd2b2ca7c8612
Can we have such a PR for release100 branch as well?
Great, thanks. Filing a separate PR was suggested by @jlahoda; I hope that I will not complicate things next time.
Looks okay to me, seems I missed looking at parameterized tests when implementing NETBEANS-6 thanks @srdo for spotting and providing a fix

@sdedic could you please revisit this? It breaks using the `full` cluster. I saw the following problem in master and bisected it to this commit:

0. start with a clean installation: `git clean -f -x -d`
1. Build the netbeans cluster with the `full` configuration: `ant -Dcluster.config=full`
2. Run `tryme`: `ant tryme`
3. Go to Plugin configuration - Menu: Tools -> Plugins
4. Switch to `Installed` tab - you see, that HTML5 is not active (expected)
5. Select the entry and choose `Activate`

Normally at this point several modules will be activated and afterwards the IDE can access the HTML5 features. Beginning with this commit various javascript modules fail to load (not sure if it is random which module fails, but I saw different names). Here is the full log from the session:

[3357fa5b18590908ac9de4ad7e55ab1fdf88cd50.log](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/files/2612462/3357fa5b18590908ac9de4ad7e55ab1fdf88cd50.log)

It would be great if you could fix this.
Just tested. It also breaks release100 branch. The HTML5 feature cannot be activated any more.
Tested before merging. It works, though cancelling the nb-javac installation also cancels the activation on JavaSE feature.
Merging to master as tested on release100

> Cancelling the nb-javac installation also cancels the activation on JavaSE feature.

So JavaSE can only be enabled with nb-javac? If I remember correctly @jlahoda put effort into enabling  at least basic IDE features with the JDK javac. If this really makes that work unusable, there should be a followup reinstating the vanilla javac work.
I'd say the current state is good enough for 10.0 - it fixes the licensing blocker. Fine tuning can happen for next version.
Sure ... I'm a bit tired of removing fallout from rash implementations (we are still suffering from the directory reorganisation ...).
JavaSE still can be enabled without nb-javac. See my comments on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1733

Hmmm, I find the UI to be fairly "not good". It does not say why it is trying to install the plugins, how to recover from the Cancel, etc.

But, can we please make this at least a little bit better for those that run on JDK where we can run without nb-javac? Something along the lines of https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1037.

> The call to `setVisible(false)` should already hide the dialog.

Yes, exactly, `setVisible(false)` is called, but somehow the dialog does not close sometimes... 

![nb-refactoring-dialog-screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/738383/48973113-7d61b880-f07b-11e8-8908-2737b0242332.png)

I'm not sure the cause correctly. It seems that the dialog is closed if the `dispose()` is added.

I noticed this problem because I looked https://netbeans.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=252972#c6
To make matters worse, I could not close the dialog even if I clicked the close button in NetBeans 8.2.
This sounds like a problem with the EDT, but the Implementation of the Refactoring dialog looks pretty sane in that regard. Cleaning up the dialog is sane, so if it helps, merge it.

Hi all,
Should we doing this for JUnit as well or not? I recall having to download the JUnit jar in previous IDE releases (Oracle era, I think), but I cannot remember why.
Thanks!
Not sure this was intentionally closed, but could we please not go down the "Ant(ic)" route? It is not funny. People choose ant for a reason and you don't need to belittle them.

@vieiro JUnit was CPL according to wikipedia that license is deemed incompatible with the GPL, so that would have prevented combination. JUnit was relicensed to EPL. EPL v1 + v2 are both cleared by apache legal and that is reflected in the existens of the `platform/libs.junit4` and `platform/lib.junit5` modules.
Thanks for the explanation @matthiasblaesing !

Thanks for the comment, I was in a hurry to get on the road and accidentally closed it. 

Agreed, I can change the name tomorrow morning, what would you suggest?
Bumping the source version to 8 is ok - 8 is the default build JDK and the lower bound.

Thank you, this reinstates the ability to use vanialla javac. What I don't see is, what we gained with #715 (If I'm not mistaken, that is the commit, that startet the automatic download)? Does it tie the installation of nb-javac to the "Java SE" feature? Before #715 there was already a hint, that asked the user to install nb-javac, was that unconditional?

One thing that is a bit ugly right now:
1. I activate Java SE
2. The IDE requires me to restart, while it does that it also pops up the question whether or not I want to install nb-javac
3. After the restart the hint is gone

Can the hint be made persistent?

Before #715. NB was automatically and unconditionally downloading nb-javac when enabling Java SE via opening projects. That's not good.

After #715, NB asks whether it should download nb-javac while opening project, but when the user says "Cancel", the IDE is thrown into a weird state, even on JDKs where we can somehow run without nb-javac.

All this patch is trying to do is to enable Java SE when the user says "Cancel" on a JDK where we can run without nb-javac, leaving the IDE (and user's impression!) in a sightly better state.

Not sure if there is a considerable amount of people that will go to Tools/Plugins and enable something there, does not seem to be a common path. The "install nb-javac" notification is used on every startup, but with a smaller severity, so that it only goes to the Notification window.
Thank you for your help, Matthias. I can't also find out problems and strange parts. If anyone else doesn't have objections, let's merge it. We can revert it soon whenever if there is a problem.
I updated the PR with a more agreeable categrory name:

The original/current names in the wizard are Java and Maven, why not now Java Maven and Java Ant? So everyone knows on the very first view what is meant here.

Followed the discussion, future wish could be only using Java maybe with sub categories or wizard enhancements. But for now I would prefer to see Java Maven and Java Ant, IMHO.

First I thought, it's only a small change, and I should do it, but actually I think the current naming is better, as it serves a purpose:

"Java Maven" and "Java Ant" does not really fix the problem of making Maven the default and "nudging" new developers to stay away from Ant. It only changes the visibility of Maven a little bit, and instead forces users to make a decision. 

Imagine a new developer who wants to create his first Java project. If we present him the options "Java" and "Java Ant", he'll very likely choose "Java", which would be great. If we present him with "Java Maven" and "Java Ant", he'll be lost and in the best case resort to google. Like Tim said on the mailing list, we force a user into a choice they don't (shouldn't) care about [For reference: Joel Spolsky's Blog Post](https://www.joelonsoftware.com/2000/04/12/choices/) explaining why this is a bad solution.

I'd prefer to keep the names like this, as a tool to point users in the right direction.

I would concur with @Chris2011 and go with "Java Ant" and "Java Maven" or "Java (ant)" and "Java (maven)". If the label is not present and I want to create a maven project, I have to guess how to get there (you are hindering my experience in that case).

Yes, as a developer you have to know some terms and if you don't know them, you should better learn.
Seems to me the PR does more than just change an icon.

@emilianbold yes, I had to create a DataObject for the file to set a different icon. Otherwise it wont work. Or maybe I didn't know any other solution, maybe there is another one :). But it seems that I can't use it, I'm in contact with the tech support for npm. Will let you know.
We logged a jira bug to follow up and fix the licensing issue : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1736

If you don't say, that "Java" means "Maven" how should an experienced user know hat netbeans does when he clicks "Next"? You still ask the user to make a decision and then you hide the important information. So if I can choose between:

- Java
- Ant Java

how should I know which is the right one, given that I want to create a maven project? Behind "Java" everything could hide (gradle, maven, make, $newCoolBuildsystem).

For me (yes, I'm also a user) hiding the build system makes the situation worse.
Logged a jira bug to follow up the licensing issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1756
Ready for review, I'd say. Please take a look. Thanks. CCing @tzezula, @thurka, @timfel, @sdedic
Are we ready to merge this?
Ready to merge this?
Who's "we"? Me? Yes, I support merging.Toni? Yes. Community? Likely. Matthias? No.

> If you don't say, that "Java" means "Maven" how should an experienced user know hat netbeans does when he clicks "Next"? 

Just like it worked for last 20 years: If you select a project, a description is displayed, which also says how this project is built. You can see that in the 2nd and 3rd screenshot "A simple Java Application using Maven."...

I'm 0 - For what it's worth, I agree with @matthiasblaesing I think making Maven (feel) default is good, but I don't necessarily agree with hiding the build system, including from newbies (a few conversations I've had recently have made me question whether doing that is a good idea).  Although the description is better than the Ant one.  Isn't having the same category and title as before potentially confusing for anyone finding old info online though?

Hi @ebarboni I don't think https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/4f98d5b61eb81ea88f1e441a517dbb8864ff20ee is worth it since this is a "release" javadoc. The timestamp trick makes sense if were to push the same javadoc multiple times (as this would reduce the number of diffs), but we're pushing the 9.0 javadocs just once.

Would be nice to have the netbeans-vm workflow for pusblishing or a pointer to so I can integrate with some builds.

@lkishalmi will do that.
should you be adding new tests to TestOutputListenerProviderTest.java to cover the new output as well? this regexp matching has always been a tricky business.

Hi srdo,
I just made a PR (https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1042) to fix the issue. I spend some time investigating the issue and made sure that my patch works with the "Print Maven output logging level" turned on and off as well as with surefire plugin version like:
2.18
2.18.1
2.19.1
3.0.0-M3
3.0-SNAPSHOT
I've the same remark as you concerning the mocking of classes to create a good unit test. I miss mockito and I prefer not to spend time or break something in the NB build to add such libraries as the NB build is not (yet?) Maven based.
@jmborer Thanks, your PR looks good. I'll close this and mark the issue as a duplicate.

Sorry, only just noticed this because of the Release100 one.  I know I made a few more changes to the output from `export2html.xsl`, both changing the title in head and a lot of the body text / links to refer to Apache.  https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans-docs/blob/asf-site/content/9.0/javadoc/overview-summary.html  I started editing `export2html.xsl` but then ended up editing the output file instead for some reason that escapes me now.  Obviously needs to go into the xsl file.

Longer term it might be good if we could switch on a release flag (or even the version number) so that release and dev text variants can remain in the file?

Also be good to get the Release100 one in at least before the vote so that checking out the tag for 10.0 can build the correct Javadoc.  Obviously not an option for this one.

As per comment on #1022 possibly needs a few more changes in `export2html.xsl` to update links / Apache info? But good to get this in to the branch prior to the next vc so that the release tag Javadoc builds correctly.

Thank you guys for taking care of this one. Created NETBEANS-1762 tracking this issue. (and to have a the to-do list ruler for the next release manager.)

Pe 30 nov. 2018, la 10:15, Svatopluk Dedic <notifications@github.com> a scris:

> @sdedic commented on this pull request.
> 
> In platform/o.n.core/src/org/netbeans/core/NbLifecycleManager.java:
> 
> > @@ -169,6 +169,10 @@ private void finishExitState(CountDownLatch cdl, boolean clean) {
>      
>      @Override
>      public void exit(int status) {
> +        if (isExiting()) {
> I think this guard breaks behaviour specified in LifecycleManager.exit API docs. The call should not return if the system is (still) willing to exit.

I've just built the branch and successfully enabled `HTML5` feature in `Tools/Plugins`. E.g. the problem reported in [NETBEANS-1159](https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/NETBEANS/issues/NETBEANS-1159) seems to be fixed. I am continuing testing...

@jmborer Thank you for adding them :)
@mkleint Thank you for reviewing it! It seems that unit tests were added. So, if it's OK with you, we can (squash and) merge this :)

I am trying to test the installation scenarios with as clean setup as possible. After getting the branch I did:
```bash
$ rm -rf *; git checkout -f . Â Â 
$ ant build
cd nbbuild
nbbuild$ rm -rf netbeans/ testuserdir/; unzip NetBeans-dev-*-ab822e2c9354-release.zip
```
the last command is useful to prevent the AutoUpdate to modify the shared installation. Then start with:
```bash
$ ant tryme
```
e.g. launch with an empty userdir. After  ab822e2 I managed to start and:
- enable *HTML5* feature via _Tools/Plugins_
- enable *JavaFX* feature via _Tools/Plugins_ (on _JDK8_ and _JDK11_)
- enable *PHP* feature via _Tools/Plugins_
- enable *Developing NetBeans* feature via _Tools/Plugins_

it always downloads necessary bits and seems to work. Also enabling features on demand, by _New Project_ works:
- tested on _Developing NetBeans_
- tested on _Java_
- tested on _PHP_

I have found small glitch and reported it as [NETBEANS-1765](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-1765). I don't think it is essential to block integration of this PR.

I'd say: overall this is a great work. If others can verify, then please integrate.

Merged. I'm testing the cherry picked version against release100 then push back if if it is Ok.

It seems this patch depends on a previous one https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/commit/4b8d8a788dce05c60444c35c895c3be5bc373537 which is not on the release100 branch (it is easy but not trivial to cherry pick that commit, require a manual delete of a file). Applying both commits makes Java projects loadable on Java 9+ (Tested on Java 11 and Java 8) even when canceling nb-javac install.

Right now I'd say I'm not intending to cherry pick both of these commits to release100, as master accumulated several changes around UC lately. Please advise!

This is a quite important PR regarding release100. Unfortunately cannot be easily cherry picked over. It conflict the nb-javac install fixes https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1037 and probably other parts as well. When this is ready I'd like to ask a separate PR for this fix based on the current release100 codebase.

Can this PR be merged now? Or is there someone who wants Toni to organize a vote on the mailing list?

My feeling is that there exists a majority that is either +1 or +0 on the "Maven 1st UI change" and this PR is good enough to begin our move towards that direction. A formal vote would of course verify/reject my feeling properly. 

Speakup if you want Toni to initiate such vote.
I agree with merging this. Would we cherry pick this for Apache NetBeans 10?

There is always the option to cancel the PR and rethink. My opinion stands, I want our users to make informed decisions and that means he/she should know what he/she chooses. You plan to take away that information . For me this is a step back.

The quoted article [Joel on Software - Choices](https://www.joelonsoftware.com/2000/04/12/choices/) does not even apply here. It argues, that useless decisions should not be presented to the user, which this PR does not do, it leaves all options accessible. It explicitly does not state, that information should be hidden from the user, which hinders the decision process.
Seems OK to me.

Wow, very cool. :-)
Rebased on latest master + merged with [PR-1037](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1037) changes

Certainly not eligible for cherry picking into NetBeans 10. We need more time to stabilize and polish the change.

@matthiasblaesing and/or everyone else, please explicitly state you insist on a **vote**. Otherwise I'll push forward merging of this PR on the basis of lazy consensus.
I don't insist on a vote, I want a better solution. I veto the merge of this PR.

Hi all,

I have to agree with @matthiasblaesing and I think this deserves some further consideration/thought, preferably in the mailing list. Matthias is putting the user first, and that's my motto as well, so I have to agree with his veto.

Trying to be positive, I'd rather see a "Java" main section with the following options:

- Ant based project.
- Maven based project.

Also let's try to be positive about ant. Apache Ant is a companion project in the ASF and deserves our consideration. The fact that it's an "old technology" deserves a respect as well. Ant has served NetBeans well during many years, and we still depend on it to build our own food.

@viero I think everyone here tries to put the user first. In my personal opinion, the PR does that, and the other solution would be confusing and bad for the user. You have a different opinion. That's OK and I respect that. But please don't assume that I don't care about usability. If you read my replies you should be able to see that my whole argument is about usability, and I'd be glad if you could respect that too, even if you don't agree.

@matthiasblaesing There was a "Java" category before, which defaulted to ANT, now it defaults to Maven. How is this a step back? It is a change of the default for Java, no more no less. And regarding the "Choices" blog, that Tim Boudreau mentioned on the mailing list: For a Java newbie it's exactly the same as the "optimize database" example in the blog: We ask the user for a decision he very likely doesn't care about and doesn't have enough information to make (What is ANT or Maven?). And for a more experienced user it's not hard to find the information, as it is in the description of the wizard.
